#Text=Grow Dandelions
#Text=Dandelions are known for their bright yellow flowers , dark green leaves , and seed-spreading puffballs that children love to blow on !
#Text=While they are largely considered to be weeds , dandelions can be harvested and used in many ways , and may possibly have some health benefits .

#Text=Dandelions are edible from root to flower , and people often use them in herbal medicine to treat conditions of the liver , bile ducts , and gallbladder , as well as for minor problems like bloating and indigestion .
#Text=Start growing dandelions in your garden or in pots to ensure that you always have a supply of these useful plants on hand !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Planting Dandelion Seeds
#Text=Gather or purchase some seeds .
#Text=Dandelions grow wild and you can easily harvest their seeds when the plant is in the seed phase .
#Text=This is when the top of the plant looks like a puffball .
#Text=Each of the little feathery strands has a seed attached to it , so you can collect these in a bag or other small container and take them home for planting .
#Text=If you prefer to purchase dandelion seeds , then check your local garden center or look for seeds online .
#Text=Wild dandelion greens may have a bitter taste , while cultivated dandelion greens will not be as bitter .
#Text=Choose a sunny location to grow your dandelions .
#Text=Dandelions do best when they have full sunlight for a large part of the day , so choose a sunny location in your garden or plan to place potted dandelions in a sunny window .
#Text=Try going out in your yard a few times throughout the day to scope out the sunniest spot .
#Text=For example , you could go outside at 8 am , 12 pm , and 4 pm and note where the sun is at by placing a few rocks on the edges of where the sun is shining .
#Text=If you will mainly be using dandelions for their leaves , then growing them in partial shade is a better option .
#Text=This will help to reduce the bitterness of the leaves and the number of flowers it produces .
#Text=Sow the seeds for flowers or greens .
#Text=The dandelion seed will need to be apart for flowers and apart for greens .
#Text=Flowers will need more room than baby dandelion greens because they will have deeper roots .
#Text=Measure the distance between your seeds to ensure that they will have plenty of room .
#Text=Leave the seeds uncovered if you are planting indoors .
#Text=You will not need to worry about the seeds getting blown out .
#Text=Dandelions do best in a shallow bed .
#Text=Do not plant your dandelions in an area with poor drainage or a tightly packed soil , such as clay .
#Text=Use a garden fork to loosen the soil before you plant if it is tightly packed .
#Text=Use a loosely packed potting soil with added compost as the growing medium .
#Text=Water the dandelions regularly .
#Text=Dandelions need a lot of water to thrive , so plan to water them regularly .
#Text=However , do not water them too much .
#Text=Water just enough so that the soil feels moist .
#Text=Check the soil by poking your finger into it once every 2 to 3 days .
#Text=If the soil feels moist , then they do not need water yet .
#Text=If it feels dry , then give them some water .
#Text=Harvesting Dandelions
#Text=Cut leaves near the base of the plant .
#Text=Use a sharp pair of garden shears to snip the leaves away from the base of the plant .
#Text=Cut as many individual leaves as needed or cut the entire rosette of greens from the root .
#Text=You may also leave the smaller leaves to continue growing if desired .
#Text=You can harvest the dandelion greens when they are small for the mildest flavor , or wait until they are larger if you prefer a bitter flavor .
#Text=Cut flowers when they have just opened .
#Text=If left too long , dandelion flowers will convert to seed distributing puffballs .
#Text=This means that you might end up with an infestation of dandelions rather than a controlled crop of them .
#Text=To prevent this from happening , cut the dandelion flowers right after they bloom .
#Text=Use a pair of sharp garden shears to cut the flowers at the base of the stem near the leaves .
#Text=You can cut the flower from the stem after harvesting and discard the stems .
#Text=Dig up roots after the flowers have bloomed .
#Text=The roots of the dandelion should be large enough to harvest after the flowers have bloomed , but you can even harvest roots of dandelions that have gone to seed .
#Text=To harvest the roots , insert a garden spade into the ground about from the base of the dandelion .
#Text=Dig around the dandelion to loosen the dirt and make it easier to pull up , and then pull the dandelion root out of the ground .
#Text=You may be able to pull up younger dandelion roots without digging since they tend to be shallower than mature ones .
#Text=Dandelions are perennials in most climates .
#Text=Leave the plant in place if you want to have it come back every year .
#Text=Using Dandelions
#Text=Add fresh dandelion greens to salads , smoothies , and stir-fry dishes .
#Text=Young , small dandelion greens , also known as baby dandelion greens , are mild in flavor , so they are great in salads and smoothies .
#Text=However , mature dandelion greens ( larger ones ) will taste best if you stir-fry them with other ingredients and seasonings , because they can have a bitter flavor .
#Text=Try sautéing dandelion greens with onions and garlic and a little bit of olive oil for a healthy veggie side dish .
#Text=Use new dandelion flowers to make beer , wine , and jelly .
#Text=If you like to make your own beer or wine , look up recipes for beer or wine made with dandelions .
#Text=You can also use the flowers to make a jelly that you can spread on toast .
#Text=You can also fry dandelion flowers for a tasty snack !
#Text=Dry dandelion roots and use them for tea .
#Text=The roots of dandelions are often used to make tea .
#Text=Dry the roots using a food dehydrator or by putting them out in the sun on a baking sheet .
#Text=Then , chop the roots up into pieces and store them in a glass jar .
#Text=To make a cup of dandelion tea , place 1 teaspoon of the dried root pieces into of boiling water and let it steep for 3 to 5 minutes .
#Text=Strain the tea and enjoy once it is cool enough to drink !
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Dandelion seeds
#Text=Potting soil
#Text=Pot or garden bed
#Text=Garden spade
#Text=Garden shears or scissors
